title: Franklin’s Revelation
logline: Inside Jason’s studio, Franklin reveals the elaborate truth behind the so-called scam: the fake conflict, the staged theft, the mugging, the actors, and his secret goal to launch Jason’s career through a documentary series.

setting.environment: Calm but tense atmosphere; studio lights partially on; everyone gathered after the chaotic heist.

JASON_TOWNE.objective: Get answers from Franklin; determine what is real.

FRANKLIN_B_STEVENSON.objective: Reveal the truth, secure Jason’s trust, and finalize his deal.

STACEY.objective: Come clean as part of Franklin’s reveal.

CATHERINE.objective: Help ease Jason into accepting the truth.

story_beats.description: Everyone settles into the studio; tension fills the room.
Franklin congratulates Jason, triggering Jason’s anger.
Franklin hands Jason a bag with the promised $50k reward.
Jason accuses him of giving more fake cash.
Franklin reveals Randal was an actor working for him.
Stacey and Catherine confess they were also hired by Franklin.
Jason confronts Catherine; Catherine frames the project as art.
Franklin claims Jason breaking the contract was planned.
Franklin explains his philosophy: Jason was 'stuck' and needed to be pushed.
Jason demands to know Franklin’s true motive.
Franklin reveals he is producing a documentary series about 'scam artists'.
Franklin explains the studio deal and the $100k-per-doc budget.
Jason wrestles with the ethics but acknowledges the payoff.
Franklin expresses admiration and hints at a future friendship.
Franklin asks Jason for a favor, ending the scene on suspense.

dialogue.line: I want to start by saying, BRAVO!
Bravo? You scammed me with fake cash! You scammed her too!
Oh yes... Here’s the fifty thousand dollar reward for stealing the painting.
What— more bullshit money? I think you need to leave.
Yeah, what’s with all the fake paper?
You think it’s fake? Why’s that?
I assumed so after all this bullshit. I talked to another artist, Randal. He told me about your scam.
Did you inspect the cash? It's real.
I inspected it. It’s good prop money.
It’s real… You were made to think it’s not. Randal works for me.
Also, Stacey and Catherine work for me. They’re being well paid.
Sorry, I couldn’t tell you anything.
So it’s all a setup!? You too? What’s in this for you?
Yes, I’m happy to be involved. I’m not an art dealer—I’m an artist too.
Okay… But I just broke the contract by stealing the painting back.
True. But that was part of my plan. Even the security guard was instructed to let only you steal it.
Why?
You were stuck. You've been waiting for good things to happen. Now you've launched.
So you think all this bullshit was necessary? You robbed us!
I know. But you were in a holding-pattern. I broke you out.
What’s in this for you?
I pitched a documentary series. Artists who think they’re being scammed. The studio loved it.
They gave me a $100,000 budget for each documentary.
So you're a filmmaker… not an art collector?
I'm both. And I want the world to know you.
Take the money. Your documentary will help people. I’ll cherish your commission.
Well… it’s been a crazy few weeks. But it’s paid off.
Wonderful. I sense a potential friendship in our future.
Maybe so… What happens now?
I have a favor to ask you…

themes: Blurred lines between truth and performance
The ethics of mentorship and exploitation

setup_payoffs.Randal’s warning: Revealed as part of Franklin’s deception.
setup_payoffs.Security guard: Was secretly instructed to allow Jason’s theft.
setup_payoffs.Catherine/Stacey’s roles: Payoff to earlier suspicions about loyalty.
